question: Say Matt, I'll have to have some money for those Manville payrolls.
answer: How much?

question: About twenty-four thousand. Yeah.
answer: Here's twenty-five thousand. Say, do me a favor, will you Charlie?

question: Yeah.
answer: Let me have ten bucks? Charlie!

question: Yeah?
answer: Now listen Charlie. I'll give you an I.O.U. I'll give you a note, I'll pay your mortgage, it's a matter of life and death

question: Whose death?
answer: It'll be yours if you don't kick in with that ten bucks.

question: Say pal, did you ever hear of a Depression?
answer: Aw, nerts!

question: Come over and see us sometime.
answer: I'm not asking you to pay off the Depression. I'm only asking you for ten bucks! That mug reminds me of a guy with his second dollar.

question: Search me. Not yet, Mr. Clark.
answer: When he comes in, tell him we're waiting for him in the board room.

question: Yes, sir.
answer: And tell him not to delay.

question: Yes, sir. Takes more than two tons of directors to make trouble for my boss.
answer: I've sent for the cashier, gentlemen. He has a list of the loans that Dickson made last month. And as I told you at breakfast, it is time we did something about it.

question: He'll stand for it, if I have anything to say about it.
answer: Here's the list.

question: Yes, thank you.
answer: Anything else?

question: With what?
answer: The ten dollars. Yes. No.

question: Oh, you think I'm lying?
answer: Yes.

question: All right, I'm lying. Don't forget you called me a liar.
answer: Oh, Matt.

question: Good morning. You're on time this morning. It's about time. Good morning, Mr. Dickson.
answer: John, how's your wife this morning? Got a handkerchief?

question: Excuse me
answer: Wait a minute.

question: I'm feeling fine this morning.
answer: That makes it unanimous. I feel all right too.

question: Thank you!
answer: You know the rules about smoking . .

question: I haven't any.
answer: You haven't got a uniform?

question: No, sir.
answer: My goodness, you ought to have a uniform. How much does one cost?

question: Why, I don't know.
answer: You see Sampson. Tell him I sent you. You've got to have a uniform.

question: Good morning, Mrs. Pembroke.
answer: Good morning, Mr. Dickson.

question: Got my letter?
answer: Yes, thank you.

question: Hello, Helen.
answer: Good morning.

question: Helen, you're becoming more beautiful every day. What are we going to do about it?
answer: I don't know.

question: Guess we'll just have to sacrifice the bank. When are you and Matt going to get married? Ummm. Stalling, eh?
answer: Why, the directors are waiting for you in the board room.

question: Directors, eh? Long faces?
answer: Mr. Dickson?

question: Ah, Mrs. Pembroke. I spoke to Mr. Schaffer at the Guaranty. He's going to take care of that mortgage for you . . . Where are you? . . . Sure, well, come on down right away. Huh? . . . Yes, of course I remember. It's tonight.
answer: But, Mr. Dickson, I thought you were going to take care of the mortgage. I only want ten thousand. The property is worth sixty.

question: That's a fair question, Schultz. Now let's see how bad a risk Jones is. What's his history? He's been a successful business man for thirty-five years. Two years ago business started falling off. Today Jones needs money, and if he doesn't get it, he goes into bankruptcy and throws nine hundred men out of work. Answer - unemployment.
answer: It also means his creditors aren't paid. They're in trouble. They go to banks and are turned down . . . more bankruptcies

question: It's a vicious circle, my friends, and the only place to cure it is right here at the source. Help Jones and you help the whole circle. Now, when Jones comes to me, I ask myself two questions. First - is he honest? Yes. Second - is he as good a business man as he was before? And the answer is - he's better .
answer: He is not only older and wiser, but his present trouble has taught him precaution. In my estimation, gentlemen, Jones is no risk. Neither are the thousands of other Joneses throughout the country

question: That's your funeral. We've got fifty thousand dollars comin' to us.
answer: I'm sorry, Dude, butI

question: That don't do us any good.
answer: But after all, you can't take blood from a stone.

question: There's plenty of it in this bank - laying around loose. Why not? All you gotta do is fix a few things for us , and we'll do the rest, see?
answer: No, no, I couldn't - I couldn't do anything like that. I

question: How-do-you-do, Mrs. Dickson.
answer: Is that busy husband of mine busy?

question: I'm afraid so.
answer: Helen, did you ever try competing with a bank?

question: No.
answer: Well, take my word for it, and don't try it. It's useless! If it were some other woman, I could handle her, but after all, you can't scratch a bank's eyes out now, can you?

question: Hardly.
answer: Oh, well. I guess the only other thing for me to do is to go out and buy myself a few sticks of dynamite. When he comes out, you tell him I'll be back. He hasn't gotten rid of me!

question: But Dude, listen - couldn't we make this some other time? Why, I needed a No, no, of course not. Not at all. Oh, here.
answer: What is the matter with you? You're trembling? Me?

question: Being alone with you has always done this to me. You know that.
answer: For a celebrated bounder, that is an awful admission. Besides, I never knew that any female could do this to you

question: Well, you can. You always could. If I thought you were the slightest bit interested, I would.
answer: Not bad, not bad at all. Do you know something? I've always been curious about your line.

question: Line?
answer: Whatever it is that makes you such a riot with women.

question: Tonight? Yes, yes, it does. What are you doing tonight, Phyllis?
answer: See, we're getting along famously!

question: Most of the creditors I know personally. I've seen them grow up in the community. I knew their fathers and mothers before them.
answer: I know, Dickson. That's all very well. But you're taking too many chances. In these times a bank should keep liquid in case of trouble. In case of emergency!

question: I know what you mean by that. You want me to hang on to our cash. Well, I don't believe in it. The law demands that I carry a certain legal reserve, and I'm doing it. The rest of our money is out working . . . working to help industry . . . to help build up business
answer: In the meantime, you're jeopardizing the safety of the bank. Well, we won't stand for it!

question: You have to stand for it. Go ahead - take all the action you want! I'm running this bank my way. Get that clear!
answer: Gentlemen, you notice Mr. Dickson refuses to consider our wishes. He refuses an offer to merge with the New York Trust - the only thing that will put this bank on safe ground. He insists upon running a bank on so flimsy a thing as . . . as faith!

question: Tonight, Oh, never! Tonight I have reserved for a very special occasion. Believe it or not, it's our wedding anniversary. Tom doesn't probably even remember it. But then, they never do, do they? But I'm giving a party for him - a real, old-fashioned surprise party. Caps, bells, whistles, and everything. I'm really terribly excited about it. I've been planning it for months.
answer: Now Phyllis, if you don't invite me, I'm coming anyway.

question: Don't be silly, Cyril. These are respectable people. They'd probably bore you to death. No.
answer: I want to be near you!

question: What?
answer: Don't you know I've been crazy about you for years? I've loved you ever since I can remember, long before you married Tom Dickson. No. No, I'm not. I deliberately avoided you. I was afraid of making a fool of myself. But I won't stand it any longer

question: Cyril!
answer: Please forgive me, Phyllis. I lost my head for a minute. But I couldn't help it, Phyllis.

question: It's all right. Thanks.
answer: And what's more, keep up the good work and who knows - some day you'll be the fellow sitting behind that desk . . What's the matter? You don't seem very excited about it.

question: Aw, I'm sorry, Mr. Dickson. It's just kind of sudden, that's all.
answer: Aw, go on, forget it. You came through, didn't you? That's all I wanted. A lot of them didn't think you would. You don't know how much satisfaction it's been to me. It's been swell. Well, when are you and Helen going to get married?

question: Well, I
answer: I suppose you want me to fix that up for you too, eh? Well, look who's here! Hello, dear.

question: What's the matter, Matt? Gee, I thought you'd be thrilled to death.
answer: Come here.

question: Well . . . ?
answer: Well, he was making love to her. I tell you, I saw them!

question: In Cluett's office?
answer: Yes, right in his office, the rat. I'd like to take a crack at that guy.

question: What's the matter dear? What have I done now?
answer: Nothing. Tom, I thought you were going out with me tonight.

question: Oh, I did have a date with you tonight, didn't I?
answer: Yes.

question: I'm terribly sorry. I'd forgotten all about you. I'm so sorry, dear.
answer: Now Tom, you simply cannot go to Philadelphia tonight. That's all there is to it.

question: But I have to go, dear. It's a very important banker's meeting. Listen, it isn't so terribly important. We can go to the theatre any time.
answer: The theatre?

question: That's what it was you planned, wasn't it? You can take some of the girls. You can take Mildred - or Gwynn
answer: The girls! I don't suppose it ever occurred to you that I might go out and find myself an attractive young man . . .

question: Ho! Ho! Ho!
answer: Ho, ho, ho, yourself! I wouldn't laugh if I were you. You may not suspect it, but I'm still attractive - to some.

question: Listen, don't go around being attractive to anyone but me . . .
answer: Well . . .

question: Don't you forget that I'm still the head man around here too. Now we'll get the tickets changed for tomorrow night. You and I are going out together. How's that?
answer: Tomorrow night?

question: Yes?
answer: Oh, I don't care, darling. I love you, anyway.

question: All right. Send him in. Well, Sampson, what is it?
answer: Here's the data on the Clyde deal.

question: Good. I'll take this along with me. Tell Clyde I'll see him tomorrow. I'm sick and tired of the delay.
answer: I'm afraid he's been stalling.

question: That's just exactly what he has been doing. This deal should have been closed weeks ago. Tell him to keep tomorrow open . . .
answer: He says he can't get away in the daytime.

question: How about his nights? He's too busy running around. Tell him to keep tomorrow night open, come in and sign this thing, or I'll call this whole deal off.
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Where's Charlie?
answer: What's keeping you?

question: Oh, Charlie again.
answer: Say Matt, you haven't done anything about what you saw today, have you? Oh now, don't be silly. Now you've got me worried, dear.

question: Okay, honey - but just the same I'd like to take a crack at that
answer: Shh . . . !

question: Are the payrolls ready for tomorrow?
answer: Yes, sir. Now?

question: Yes, now.
answer: All right, sir.

question: Have you the correct time? 12:05. Fine. My apartment. Come on up for just a few minutes. We'll have just one drink, then we'll go. What's the matter? Afraid papa will spank?
answer: No. No, I'm afraid papa isn't that much interested. He's too busy rushing off to Philadelphia to make stuffy, old speeches at stuffy, old bankers' meetings. Too busy closing big, important deals

question: Good for you. Come on.
answer: You know, there ought to be a Congressional Medal for men like you. America's comfort to misunderstood wives. I never thought I would find myself in that class.

question: Oh, you're not so badly off. There's something much worse than being a misunderstood wife.
answer: What is that, Mr. Bones?

question: The butler said I could stay. I told him it was important.
answer: Oh, yeah?

question: He's not here. He left at nine o'clock. He said you gave him the night off.
answer: What do you want?

question: Do you mind stepping outside? We could talk Oh no, Mr. Cluett, if it's all the same to you, I'd rather not wait. It's about you and Mrs. Dickson. You've no right to do this to her, Mr. Cluett. Why don't you think it over? It's only gonna get you into a lot of trouble.
answer: I tell you, I'm not interested in your opinion.

question: Blood! I was the first one to see it. I was coming down the stairs, and there was the watchman lying dead at my feet.
answer: No kidding?

question: No kidding. When I saw it, you coulda knocked me over with a pin.
answer: Where's Matt?

question: Matt?
answer: Yeah. He'll have a tough time thinking up a wise-crack for this one . . .

question: The detectives got Matt up there in Sampson's office.
answer: He has?

question: Now don't you worry about it.
answer: Then you did it and you did it alone I'm afraid I must, Mr. Dickson.

question: Why pick on him ?
answer: It's an inside job. That's a cinch. Whoever did it had a pretty good picture of the layout. Now Brown, here, is in charge of the vaults, isn't he?

question: Then who changed it?
answer: Wait a minute. Wait a minute. What time did this thing happen?

question: The clock opposite the vault was stopped by a bullet at 12:09.
answer: All right. If the boy proves an alibi, he's all right, isn't he?

question: If he can do it, yes.
answer: Why, certainly he can.

question: Yes, sir. I was having me hot mustard bath.
answer: What time was it?

question: for the rheumatism, you know.
answer: What time was it, Mrs. Halligan?

question: It was late, I know. The Dooley sisters was already in. They work at a show, you know.
answer: What time was it?

question: Huh?
answer: What time did Matt Brown get in?

question: Now, let me see - a half hour after the Dooley sisters - and the Dooley sisters never get home until after That's just what I'm trying to tell you, sir. It was a half hour after the Dooley sisters . . .
answer: Was it twelve o'clock?

question: No, it wasn't twelve - 'cause the Dooley sisters . . . Yes, I guess it was one, 'cause . . No. It wasn't earlier because . . .
answer: Yes, I know. Cause the Dooley sisters weren't in yet.

question: Look at them, Mr. Dickson. They're going crazy.
answer: Did you get the case for the securities?

question: Yes, sir.
answer: Mine too?

question: Yes, sir. But soon as our money runs out, they'll mob the place.
answer: The fools! If they only knew it, they're making things worse for themselves. Somebody starts a silly rumor, and they lose their heads.

question: What'll we do?
answer: I'll talk to them. Listen, go back and tell the boys to stall as much as possible. Tell 'em not to pay any attention to what I said. Tell 'em to verify every signature. Take your time, folks. Don't get excited. Everybody stay in line. You'll all be taken care of. Don't worry about anything. Plenty of time for everything. Now listen, everybody! Listen to me! I want you to know that your money is safe. This bank is in excellent condition. If you've heard any reports to the contrary, it's based on malicious rumors.

question: What did you find out, Mike? Never mind all that. What did you find out? Dude Finlay?
answer: Did you say Dude Finlay?

question: Yes, why?
answer: He was in the bank yesterday. He came to see Mr. Cluett.

question: Are you sure?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: You want the rest of those numbers, Mr. Dickson?
answer: What's he doing, honey? Is he getting any help?

question: Something's happened. He isn't trying anymore.
answer: They must have turned him down.

question: Yes. He called some of the biggest people in town.
answer: Sure, they'd turn him down. He ought to know that. I'm going in there and talk to him. We haven't got much time left, Mr. Dickson. We've got to do something quick or it'll be too late.
